title: Serenade: A Singing Style Conversion Framework Based On Audio Infilling
author: Lester Phillip Violeta (Graduate School of Informatics Nagoya University), Wen-Chin Huang (Graduate School of Informatics Nagoya University), Tomoki Toda (Information Technology Center Nagoya University), ...
relevance_why: The paper discusses a framework for singing style conversion, which aligns with Dr. Liu's focus on audio processing and generative audio models. The audio infilling method could complement the techniques used in text-to-audio generation.
background: The task involves transforming the singing style of an audio signal while preserving melody, effectively retaining the original notes without distorting the singer's identity.
contribution: This paper introduces the Serenade framework to solve the challenge of singing style conversion, achieving high similarity in converted singing styles, particularly in breathy and mixed styles.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior methods in singing voice conversion typically focus on speaker identity without adequately addressing style transformations.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by utilizing an audio infilling method combined with cyclic training and a source-filter vocoder, effectively modeling diverse singing styles.

key_innovation: Employs an audio infilling task coupled with a cyclic training mechanism to enable better disentanglement of singing styles while retaining melody fidelity.
real_world_impact: The framework could significantly enhance applications in music production and vocal synthesis, potentially improving accessibility in music creation tools.
limitations: The paper notes some trade-offs between naturalness and similarity when applying F0 resynthesis.

new_terms.audio infilling: **Audio infilling** refers to the task of predicting masked segments of audio data using contextual information from surrounding segments.
new_terms.cyclic training: **Cyclic training** is a model training approach that incorporates the output of a model back into the training to refine and improve its performance.

open_sourcing: The code and pretrained models are available at https://github.com/lesterphillip/serenade
